item.description: […] my last Fri­day Go For­ward post, I men­tioned the fact that I was feel­ing appre­cia­tive of the fact that turn based go is […]

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: I'm with you on that. In fact, you'll probably empathize with my post later on today. Definitely not doing as well with correspondence games as I would probably have done in a real time game. I like your advice on not needing to know where your opponent last played. =) That's something I plan on writing on in the future too, so I'm glad I'm not the only one who thinks it.
item.content:encoded:
I’m with you on that. In fact, you’ll probably empathize with my post later on today. Definitely not doing as well with correspondence games as I would probably have done in a real time game.
I like your advice on not needing to know where your opponent last played. =) That’s something I plan on writing on in the future too, so I’m glad I’m not the only one who thinks it.

item.title: By: Tyler Provick
item.dc:creator: Tyler Provick
item.description: I think my biggest problem is I don't give as much time to a move on nova.gs as I would in a real game. You figure you'll check for moves, do a bunch in your 3 games and off you go, only to look back and realize you didn't even correctly read your opponents initial response. I think the advice about knowing the last stone played is good here. Someone said that you don't need to know which stone your opponent just played because you should be reading the board and looking at what you need to defend and where you can attack.
item.content:encoded:
I think my biggest problem is I don’t give as much time to a move on nova.gs as I would in a real game. You figure you’ll check for moves, do a bunch in your 3 games and off you go, only to look back and realize you didn’t even correctly read your opponents initial response.
I think the advice about knowing the last stone played is good here. Someone said that you don’t need to know which stone your opponent just played because you should be reading the board and looking at what you need to defend and where you can attack.
